author: Yunjia Wang
description: Instruction sketch 1 - filling a pattern with infinite repetition
code:
1/ Create a 500px * 500px canvas, fill with black
2/ Stroke weight 0.5pt, color white, opacity 50%
3/ Draw a horizontal line connecting the midpoint of the left and right edges, a vertical line connecting the midpoint of the top and bottom edges.
4/ In the last step, the two intersecting lines are mutually divided into 4 segments, marked as left(L), right(R), up(U), down(D).
5/ Draw a circle, using the midpoint of segment L as the center, and the length of L as diameter. Mark the circle as Circle L.
6/ Draw a circle, using the midpoint of segment R as the center, and the length of R as diameter. Mark the circle as Circle R.
7/ Draw a circle, using the midpoint of segment U as the center, and the length of U as diameter. Mark the circle as Circle U.
8/ Draw a circle, using the midpoint of segment D as the center, and the length of D as diameter. Mark the circle as Circle D.
9/ In each circle(L, R, U, D), operate the following steps respectively:
9.1/ Draw a diameter perpendicular to the existing segment that goes through the center.
9.2/ Repeat step 4 to 8.
10/ Repeat step 9, 9.1, 9.2 infinitely.

description: Tweaking the properties and movement of some ellipses in a dark 3D space. There is only one point light constantly moving in the space, and the ellipses are drawn in 2D. author: Rosa Ng
description:
RE: Peter's instruction

I wasn't very good at following directions, totally missed the keyword "counterclockwise" in the instruction. Also, I realized I was counting the first number of the ring around the box wrong. 

Questions that came up while doing this...
1. The rule on "if there is one, color the cell red". What is "one" referring to? I assumed it's #1 box around the ring
2. How are we defining "number"? Is the number the order of the boxes in the ring or are we referring to the gird number? If it's the grid number, are we using the number of the X or Y axis?
3. When I finished, it didn't fill the entire grid but the instructions seemed like I should be able to fill the entire thing. Did I do it wrong?

comments.comment: I interpreted this waay differently hahah

author: Omar Nema
description:
Anni Albers master study
--
Spent *a lot* of time trying to get 'natural' squiggly rectangles using a bunch of points instead of rectangles but made little progress. Decided to just go with a grid, and apply shear transformation to try to make it look a bit more natural. Still looks very digital.
I used random arrangement of rectangles + stripes w/ weights and constraints. Main color is randomized, but blacks and greys are fixed.

Code here: https://github.com/omar-nema/parsons-comp-form/blob/master/Week%203/randomsketch2albers/sketch.js

author: Munro Hoberman
description: tiny agar
code:
n=128r,q=rnd,{}for i=0,n do
add(q,{r(n),r(n),3,r()})end::_::cls()for f in all(q)do
x=f[1]y=f[2]l=f[3]f[1]=(x+cos(f[4]))%n
f[2]=(y+sin(f[4]))%n
circ(x,y,l,l)f[4]+=r(.2)-.1for e in all(q)do
k=e[3]
if(l>=abs(e[1]-x)+abs(e[2]-y)and e!=f)del(q,e)f[3]=sqrt(k^2+l^2)end
end
flip()goto _

comments.comment: Nice job munro! Looks like it works well!

author: Emily Bowe
description: First try at using P5.js -- not super impressive, but I'm working on learning how to draw/animate with the library! You have to start somewhere, right?

comments.comment: Looking good! Creates interesting diamonding in that center.
Yeah! I was excited about some of the possibilities once I started playing with some of the alpha values + blendMode()

code:
<html>
  <head>
    <script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/p5@1.1.9/lib/p5.js"></script>
    <script src="sketch.js"></script>
<script>
function setup() {
    createCanvas(800, 600);
    noStroke();
    frameRate(5);
}

function draw() {
    side = (2 * height) / sqrt(3) * .75;
    drawTriangles(side / 2, side, 6);
}

function drawTriangles(top_x, side, level) {
    // blendMode(SOFT_LIGHT);
    fill(random(100, 255), random(100, 255), random(100, 255), random(100, 255));
    triangle(0, (side * sqrt(3)) / 2, 2 * top_x, (side * sqrt(3)) / 2, top_x, 0);
    
    translate()
    fill(random(100, 255), random(100, 255), random(100, 255), random(100, 255));
    triangle(0, 0, side / 2, side * sqrt(3) / 2, side, 0);
}
</script>
  </head>
  <body>
    <main>
        
    </main>
  </body>
</html>

author: Munro Hoberman
description: following douglas's instructions.
code:
q={}
for i=0,63do
add(q,{})
for f=1,30do
add(q[i],.25)
end
end
::_::
cls(1)
wind=sin(t()/2)*.02
color(11)
for i=1,#q do
line()
x=i*3-3
y=128
for f=1,#q[i]do
line(x,y)
x+=cos(q[i][f])*4
y+=sin(q[i][f])*4
d=wind+rnd(.2)-.1
d*=.08-abs(.25-q[i][f])
q[i][f]+=d
end
end
flip()
goto _

author: Bex Ruvalcaba
description: a noisy potion-inspired interactive background âš—ï¸ if anyone has any tips on how I could make the glitter movement look more liquid-like let me know! Code [here](https://editor.p5js.org/rebeccaruva/sketches/gi2M7U_-0) and interact [here](https://editor.p5js.org/rebeccaruva/present/gi2M7U_-0)

comments.comment: This is really lovely Bex! For more liquid-like behavior, there are three approaches I might take. The first is to slow or remove the glitter's return to a position and instead have them move freely in the "fluid" (you'd lose some of the noise aspects of this but!). Then two, I would look into applying a parallax effect and change how much something moves based on a depth value (that can be distributed by noise). This would give the glitter an appearance of being inside a fluid. Finally, I would have the color of the glitter move between the brighter or dimmer color (if connected to moving noise then this also as the side effect of making the glitter appear as thought it is moving forward and back within the fluid).

Thank you for the feedback, Jason!! Yes, I was thinking to myself after I finished the sketch: "hmmmm I'm probably going to have to leave out noise for my next iteration" ðŸ˜‚ (at least for the glitter position)

description:
Pen & Paper | On a grid of circles:

Pick any circle.
Pick a point at the 12, 3, 6 or 9 o clock' position. 
Pick an adjacent circle
Pick a point at the opposite side of the circle to the first point.
Connect the two points with an S curve.
Continue from the second circle until all circles are done.

author: Munro Hoberman
code:
function setup() {
  createCanvas(400, 400);
  background(220);
  past_lives=[]
  let races=[
    "human",
    "elf",
    "dwarf",
    "orc",
    "troll",
    "goblin",
    "ogre",
    "werewolf",
    "cat",
    "dog",
    "tiger",
    "giraffe",
    "rhino",
    "fish",
    "shark",
    "octopus",
    "mouse",
    "rat",
    "ladybug",
    
    "oni",

  ]
  let jobs=[
    "warrior",
    "",
    "priest",
    "archer",
    "knight",
    "paladin",
    "bard",
    "necromancer",
    "samurai",
    "wizard",
    "rogue",
    "brute",
    "cleric",
    "warlock",
    "druid",
    "barbarrian",
    "barber",    
    "accountant",
    "janitor",
    "middle-manager",
    "lawyer",
    "plumber",
    "cobbler",
    "developer",
    "tourist",
    "captain",
    "cultist",
    "pirate",
    "architect",
    "student",
    
  ]
  
  sel_race = createSelect();
  for (let i=0;i<races.length;i++) {
    sel_race.option(races[i])
  }

  sel_race.changed(selected);
  
  sel_job = createSelect();
  for (let i=0;i<jobs.length;i++) {
    sel_job.option(jobs[i])
  }
  sel_job.changed(selected);
  selected()
}


function selected() {
  let race=sel_race.value();
  let job=sel_job.value();
  background(255);
  // textSize(20);
  text('You are a ' + race + " "+ job +'!\nYou are well known for doing '+race+"ish "+job+"ty things. ", 50, 50);
  for (let i=0;i<past_lives.length;i++) {
    text("In a past life you might have been a "+past_lives[i]+"?",50,i*12+80)
  }
  past_lives.push(race+" "+job)
}

pal({1,9,3,5,13,1,12,15,11,6,7})::_::for y=-1,99do
for x=-1,9do
j=x*16+y%2*8k=y*3n=abs(j-58)m=abs(k-64)h=min(5,flr(rnd(9)*max(1-(sqrt(n*n+m*m))/70)))for i=0,h do
ovalfill(j,k-i*2,j+9,k+5-i*2,h==i and h+6 or h)end
end
flip()end
goto _

description: Learning the gift wrapping algorithm

Neat. For those that haven't heard of it, the giftwrapping algo finds the "convex hull" of points. You can find the convex hull of points by hammering nails part way into each point and pulling a rubber band around them all.

author: Munro Hoberman

comments.comment: Looking great! have any good resources for starting with L systems?

this one the code was based it off of https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/fractal-trees-python/ 

binary trees are fairly quick to get running.

code:
function l(h,i,x,y)j=x
k=y
x+=cos(h)*16y+=sin(h)*16line(x,y,j,k,7)circ(x,y,2)
if(i>6)return
for e=-1,1,2do
l(h+a*e,i+1,x,y)end
end
pal({[0]=-15,1,-13,3,-5,11,-6},1)::_::for i=0,999do
x=rnd(128)y=rnd(128)circ(x,y,1,max(pget(x,y)-1,0))end
a=t()/9l(.25,0,63,127)flip()goto _

author: Munro Hoberman
code:
poke(0x5f2d,1)
::_::
j=stat(32)
k=stat(33)
cls()
for x=.5,127,9do
for y=.5,127,9do
a=atan2(j-x,k-y)
for i=0,1,.25do
c=cos(a+i)*4
s=sin(a+i)*4
line(x+c,y+s,x,y,7)
end
end
end
flip()
goto _

author: Jiangnan Hou
description:
Made with Processing. Following Sohee's instruction:
1) draw a big square
2) mark small mid-points for each side
3) connect the points to create another square within the big square
4) repeat until you physically can't draw another one!
5) if you can, try making this computationally
